properties.description: This burger eats like a steak (a ground one, anyway): toothsome, meaty as hell, with rich, beefy flavor and just a hint of steak sauce. It comes on a tender brioche bun and is topped with the Holy Trinity of umami burger toppings: blue cheese, sautéed mushrooms, and sautéed onions, with enough slabs of sliced tomato and butter lettuce that you can convince yourself you’ve had a side salad.
properties.name: The Steakhouse Burger

properties.description: These guys take Burger Week so seriously, they sacrificed a special cow just for the event! The also sacrificed tasty shaved ham, melty Swiss cheese, house-made potato chips and delicious mango-avocado salsa. The salsa is dressed with a little twangy pickle juice, so Lift the Emburgo is like a Cuban sandwich, a hamburger, and a sexy dictator had a love child in your mouth.
properties.name: LIFT THE EMBURGO!

properties.description: If this is what it’s like to be dragged underground via a series of tunnels and sold into slavery on a Chinese labor ship, sign me up! Club 21’s Shanghai Burger is like a backyard barbecue in my mouth: a juicy beef patty with melted pepper jack cheese, zippy barbecue sauce and crunchy Napa slaw all meld together into a creamy, smoky dream.
properties.name: The Shanghai Burger

properties.description: Just for shits and gigs, I enlisted the help of Burger Week Emeritus Extraordinaire, Chris Onstad, for this one! Chris and I tried this immense burger, all laden with gooey chipotle cream cheese and housemade guac, roasted poblanos, melted pepper jack, and thick-cut bacon, and we were like, “Mang, you know what this needs? Fried onions.” AND THEY ADDED THEM. Knuckle Sandwich’s crispy-gossamer French-fried onions are now part of their extravaganza of a Burger Week burger. You’re welcome.
properties.name: The Piñata Burger

properties.description: Pimento cheese: the caviar of the South. Anything with pimento cheese (or “pimenna cheese,” as one dear Southern friend affectionately calls it) is an automatic win in my book, and that definitely includes Slowburger’s Pimento Cheese Burger. The beef? Rich and savory. Shredded iceberg, sesame seed bun? Check. Fried onions? Oh my, are you flirting with me? Pimento cheese: ON FLEEK. Shredded sharp Tillamook cheddar mashed together with cream cheese, mayo, diced pimentos, and just a whisper of smoked paprika will soothe any die-hard pimenna cheese fan’s soul.
properties.name: The Pimento Cheese Burger

properties.description: God I want to steal that S&M joke from the Guardian’s review of the Egg Master, but instead I’ll make a predictable Marc Singer reference. That said, Slowbar’s Kimchi Master burger is no joke! It’s a nice, thick beef patty topped with kimchi (mixed with chopped kale so the heat/garlic/lactofunk doesn’t beat you over the head), nestled lovingly on a swath of Jujitsu Mayonnaise—Slowbar’s homemade mayo punched up with just the right amount of wasabi. Bonus: this one’s cheese-free, for those who can’t hang with the dairy.
properties.name: Kimchi Master

properties.description: I’m woman enough to admit it: This burger nearly defeated me. The patty and bun alone are substantial, but then that sorceress in the Triple Nickel kitchen went and topped it with a mound of sautéed onions and a blanket of smoked Gouda fondue fortified with Heineken. And tangy barbecue potato chips that they make from scratch to provide crunch. And banana peppers to cut through the richness. The result can be a bit tricky to eat, but like taming a wild horse, your tenacity will be rewarded.
properties.name: Trip Nicktacular Fondue Burger

properties.description: Okay, take everything that is glorious about a cheeseburger and then DOUBLE IT. Alameda Brewhouse has taken two 3-oz. beef patties covered in melted American cheese, added thick slices of tomato, crunchy iceberg, red onion, and chunks of chopped dill pickle in secret sauce. For another $3, they’ll even throw in a can of their house brew or a shot of Jim Beam rye!
properties.name: The Smashed American

properties.description: Much like the atmosphere in the bar itself, Star's Bar's Dirty Deeds (Done Dirt Cheap) is authentic and unpretentious, yet more fun than workmanlike. An all-natural Portland French pub roll anchors a thick patty of Painted Hills ground beef heaped with caramelized onions and crispened shallots, then drenched in housemade blue cheese sauce. Lettuce and tomato deliver a bright, crunchy counterpoint, and a dijon-and-garlic spread provides the lube. In other words: All the good stuff, no bullshit.
properties.name: Dirty Deeds (Done Dirt Cheap)

properties.description: You ever think to yourself, “Man, I could really go for a gyro and a burger”? Well friend, you’re in luck! Ya Hala’s Hala Burger is a juicy lamb patty stuffed with pungent feta, slathered in cool tzatziki sauce and tahini mustard, and then topped with a thick slice of grilled tomato and frizzled onions. There’s even a little arugula for good measure. Since it doesn’t come wrapped in that foil paper that usually keeps a gyro safely contained (and comes on a brioche bun instead of wrapped in a pita), you’ll definitely need a knife and fork for this one.
properties.name: Hala Burger

properties.description: I walked out of Pause in glorious, satisfied, legitimate pain after devouring every single bit of their pork-and-beef burger. It’s got house-made tomato jam, red peppers, caramelized onions, whole milk mozzarella on a Portland French onion Kaiser roll and I would actually consider trading my soul, if I had one, for another. I set the thing down after every sloppy bite and licked my fingers, swearing I had no more room, then immediately found myself picking it back up for another smoky, spicy, wonderful bite.
properties.name: The Steakhouse Burger

properties.description: Don’t let the size of this little slider fool you—it’s a-one spicy meat-a-ball! (Sorry, had to.) Seriously, though, East Glisan’s Meatball Burger is a tower of heaven: spicy pork meatball studded with requisite minced, sautéed onion, with marinara and creamy house-pulled mozzarella melted lovingly over the top; a perfect little crispy Parmesan frico; and a bit of arugula and pickled red onions to lighten things up—all stacked Jenga-like onto a focaccia bun.
properties.name: East Glisan’s Meatball Burger

properties.description: Cream cheese and house-made chow chow (one of my favorite relishes ever!) take Double Barrel’s Dixie Burger to a magical place. It’s everything you remember from your favorite childhood fast food burger. The basic bun and patty are mercifully unfucked-with, and sweet, salty, mustard-vinegary twang of the chow chow mixes with the cream cheese in a way that perfectly encapsulates that secret sauce-American cheese combo of all my happiest burger memories.
properties.name: The Dixie Burger

properties.description: With the Kells Lamb Burger, Kells Brew Pub is serving up an Irish twist on an old favorite. Savory ground lamb on a potato roll will make you want to don your woolens, and not even the addition of feta and basil to the meat can snap you out of it. Baby arugula, thick slab of tomato and pickled red onions balance the flavors and provide brightness, while the rosemary aioli keeps the toasted bun well lubricated.
properties.name: The Lamb Burger

properties.description: The DFSW (Doug Fir Southwest), or as I call it, the NSFW, is a civilized nod to the bold flavors of the rowdy Southwest: roasted poblano peppers are tempered with a creamy dressing, subtended by a pungency reminiscent of aged blue cheese. The cooling “Inca” cabbage slaw provides necessary crunch and brightness. The real star, though, is the superb 1/3-lb Wagyu beef patty, charred to flavorful perfection. Golden shoestring fries not included, but for the love of all that is good, get them.
properties.name: DFSW

properties.description: Don’t be disappointed when you notice that Church’s Chow Chow Burger isn’t dressed in shredded cabbage and green tomatoes; this one’s made with a corn and diced celery version of the relish learned from chef Jake’s Illinois-born mom, and it is LEGIT. The expected red bell pepper adds color, whereas serranos provide a slow-building burn. The avocado crema melds nicely with the pepper jack draped over the beefy Angus patty, and the patty itself has enough char to stand up to the burger’s bold flavors.
properties.name: The Chow Chow Burger

properties.description: The Grindelwald: Because one should always have a favorite region of Switzerland, and then own an amazing bar so you can name a burger after it. Bar Bar, which churns out thousands of never-fail cheeseburgers on the regular, is offering an homage to owner Jim Brunberg’s favorite Swiss mountain region: a quarter pound grass fed beef patty with sautéed mushrooms, onions, and bacon, melted Swiss cheese, and house made garlic aioli on a toasted potato bun. This is no pinkie-up eating—the rich toppings will ooze out onto your digits but never make that potato bun’s delightfully crisp edges go soggy. Order some freedom fries if you’re feeling too Continental.
properties.name: The Grindelwald

properties.description: The toasted bun from Alessio Baking Company holds a quarter-pound burger surrounded by butter lettuce, pickles, and All-Way's own house spread, their take on Russian dressing. The beef is capped with bacon, blue cheese, two crunchy fried onion rings, and barbecue sauce. Any burger with onion rings in it pretty much wins me over. Do I want fried things up against a chunk of meat, both slathered in smoky flavor sauce? Yes. Yes I do.
properties.name: The Bacon Blue Cheese Barbecue Burger

properties.description: “I haven’t figured out what to put on top, like on a stick,” Robyn explained to me when we chatted about her buffalo burger a week before my sneak preview. Turns out, this lily doesn’t need gilding, but HOLY FUCK DID SHE GILD IT. Her gouda, bacon and roasted red pepper-topped slider is already a Thing of Beauty, but then she went and put a mozzarella stick, fried pickle slice, and a goddamn deep-fried macaroni and cheese bit on top. The slash of raw onion and yellow mustard set this German girl’s heart ablaze, but also serve to slice through the richness of all the fried goodies.
properties.name: Buffalo Burger

properties.description: Burnside Brewing’s Dirty Burger is fucking ridiculous. It’s the burger incarnation of getting ass-up drunk with all the relatives on the Oklahoma side of the family (the fun ones): a grilled beef patty and shaved country ham smothered in zippy pimento cheese sauce and browned onions, on a base of spicy Fresno chile slaw and lurid-yet-addictive Kool-Aid pickles. KOOL-AID PICKLES. This is all somehow standing upright on the most delicate, butter Kaiser roll, and then oh, what the hell, a homemade barbecue pork rind is pinned on top.
properties.name: The Dirty Burger

properties.description: Burgers are naturally mouthwatering, but before you sink your teeth in, appreciate that Smokey Joe looks like a work of art or possibly the flag of a country I’d want to emigrate to. The lightly toasted Grand Central bun frames the creation with a thick, visible layer of smoked onion cream cheese, then the char-brown Painted Hills patty, with a vibrant mixture—and crunchy texture—of house pickled slaw featuring brilliant orange carrots and yellowed cabbage, with some more of that creamy mix that replicates French onion dip. To clarify, the cream cheese is blended with smoked onions rather than onions in smoked cream cheese, but it deserves to be the new standard for cheeseburgers.
properties.name: Smokey Joe

properties.description: With a bar program that’s conceptual but unpretentious, and a food menu that delivers big flavor with little price, The Knock Back is one of my favorite bars in town. Their Le Pâté Don't Play burger is also likely to slide into Burger Week legend. It’s as high as a human hand, with a list of goodies almost as long (deep breath in): a 7 oz Painted Hills beef burger with two slices of house-made country pâté, and herbed chevre, dressed with arugula, fennel, and pickled onions with champagne vinaigrette AND THEN mustard mayo and sambal spicy mayo. As promised, this one doesn’t mess around.
properties.name: Le Pâté Don't Play

properties.description: They should call it the “Who’s Your Daddy” because I want this burger to sit me on its knee and stroke my hair and tell me I’m pretty. I am this burger’s bitch, and the Sweet Onion Burger at Portland Penny Diner is my new boyfriend. You know how Burgerville has that Walla Walla Sweet burger every summer? Well imagine if every single ingredient on it — beef patty draped in melted American cheese (do NOT front on that), local tomato, homemade zucchini bread-and-butter pickles, shredded iceberg, browned Walla Walla Sweet onions, even the secret sauce — was brought to its climax by beautiful angels, and you’re getting close. Then put it all on a tender, sesame seed bun baked in-house. This is burger perfection. NOTE TO AVOID BURGER TEARS: burger is not available for lunch, only after 4pm!
properties.name: Sweet Onion Burger

properties.description: It may be $5, but the Sleaze Burger at Smallwares is no cheap ho: fresh-ground pork butt and star anise-flecked Chinese sausage come together in a juicy patty topped with sticky-sweet peanut sauce, and a bright cilantro-Napa slaw dressed in nam pla vinaigrette. Puff-crispy fried rice noodles tossed in Korean chile powder add pop. Pickles, tomato, and sesame seed bun bring it back to familiar territory. Get the Sleazy Beezy at Lil’wares during lunch hours, and at the mothership in the evenings.
properties.name: Sleaze Burger

properties.description: White Owl’s Burger Week entry is what would happen if a burger and a gyro combined their powers, Wonder Twins-style, to form something more powerful than either could ever be on their own. The juicy lamb is immediately a departure from beef, and could be just the thing for a little variety after you've put a dozen beef patties into your face in a foolhardy (but admirable!) attempt to hit every Burger Week location. But this isn't a Mediterranean food in disguise. This is a collaboration. This is the (Middle) East meeting the West. The lamb is slathered with herbed mayo and American cheese right out of an In-N-Out, making it the kind of messy, cheese-drenched flavor bomb that so characterizes These United States. It's not a gyro: It's a melting pot in a potato bun.
properties.name: Double Lamb Burger

properties.description: Davis Street's inspiration for this dynamic Burger Week entry takes its cue from ingredients native to the Yucatán Peninsula of Mexico. The juicy patty is souped up with onions, garlic, and a little soy sauce, then gets a citrusy counterpoint with a roasted jalapeño aioli (which is perfectly mellow in case you have any spicy-foods anxiety). Heirloom tomato helps bolster this burger's fresh, crowning feature: a jicama salad with salad and chicharones—little pieces of fried pig skin. Frankly there's not enough room to fit as much as you'll want between the Yucatán's bun, so it comes with an extra dollop of salad on the side.
properties.name: The Yucatán Burger

properties.description: Iconic, the newish NE Broadway lounge with larger-than-life pics of Elizabeth Taylor and James Dean, is putting out a Hollywood luxe burger on a van-down-by-the-river budget. Behold The Goat: a lamb/goat blend on a goat-buttered and toasted rustic bun (oh-so-buttery-crunchy for reals!) with black truffle chevre and “goat food”—arugula and chives tossed with green goddess dressing. Goats will eat anything—you, human, should definitely eat this.
properties.name: The Goat

properties.description: Take a perfectly delicious cheeseburger, with everything that is right about a cheeseburger: beef patty, slices of red onion and pickles, something green (in this case, peppery baby arugula) and put it on a beautiful sesame seed brioche. Then, put a diamond ring on that bitch (or in this case, sublime roasted garlic-truffle aïoli), and you’ll have an idea of what Foster Burger’s 24k burger has in store for you. Don’t forget to add fries to sop up all that gorgeous aïoli.
properties.name: The 24k

properties.description: First thing’s first: The standard H&V Burger that guests are normally treated to is one of the finest in town. It’s the only time I like fried egg on my burger. It will still be available during Burger Week, but the price will still be $10. Meanwhile, this year’s BW creation stars an all pork patty, ground with chili flakes and Italian seasonings. It’s framed by a brioche bun from Grand Central Bakery. Providing the creamy adhesive is white cheddar cold-smoked in house over hickory. In lieu of, say, relish, there’s a pickle slaw and the house-brined pickles—gurgling with garlicky goodness—would make for a tantalizing side dish all their own. It’s further dressed with BBQ sauce and aioli, but between the spice rack’s worth of seasoning and succulent porcine patty, there’s zero fear of winding up with a dry mouth or a dry plate.
properties.name: The BBQ Pork Burger

properties.address: 500 NE Martin Luther King Jr Blvd
properties.description: Spirit of 77’s house burger is all of the best parts of a sportsball visit laid out on a bun, plus with better and cheaper beer than you’ll ever score at the Moda Center. You’ll snag their house burger (normally $10) for $5: an all-beef patty dripping with cheddar topped with pickles, onions, cabbage, mustard, catchup—and finally, the homerun hit—thick cut kettle chips tossed on for crunch. Relish it with a Heater Allen Pilsner on tap.
properties.name: The House Burger

properties.description: Frankly speaking, the Urban Cowboy burger has ruined me for all other burgers. If Widmer Brothers' intention was to build the juiciest, most accessible burger in town, they have succeeded mightily. The main contributor to this burger's juiciness is its Fulton Meats custom blend of short rib, brisket, and perfectly cooked chuck, wedged between a just-crunchy enough Grand Central poppy seed bun. Topped with Tillamook cheddar, caramelized onion, smoked onion sauce, Carlton Farm bacon, shredded iceberg, AND an amazingly delicate Ancho chili peach barbecue sauce, this is a BBQ burger that puts all others to shame—largely due to a complimentary combo of ingredients which refuse to outshine or overwhelm the others. While filling, it won't send you into a food coma, leaving room to pair it with a brisk, refreshing Upheaval IPA. So run, don't walk to get this one... the Urban Cowboy burger is scrape-the-plate good.
properties.name: Urban Cowboy

properties.description: This is Elephants' first time in the Burger Week game, but they've been watching. One of the things they've noticed is that while lots of Burger Week burgers draw from ethnic cuisines around the world, few focus on the Bavarian and Eastern European regions. The Pig Lebowski definitely rights that oversight. The ground pork patty also contains kielbasa sausage, a bit of bacon, caraway, and thyme. Add to that a stoneground mustard and mayo sauce and a generous portion of a delicious red cabbage slaw studded with pickle pieces. It all fits very nicely between two sliced of the house-baked-daily sesame bun. And to those who wonder if the Burger Week stampede will threaten their ability to deliver all hand-done patties, Elephants says, 'Bring it.'
properties.name: The Pig Lebowski

properties.description: This is Elephants' first time in the Burger Week game, but they've been watching. One of the things they've noticed is that while lots of Burger Week burgers draw from ethnic cuisines around the world, few focus on the Bavarian and Eastern European regions. The Pig Lebowski definitely rights that oversight. The ground pork patty also contains kielbasa sausage, a bit of bacon, caraway, and thyme. Add to that a stoneground mustard and mayo sauce and a generous portion of a delicious red cabbage slaw studded with pickle pieces. It all fits very nicely between two sliced of the house-baked-daily sesame bun. And to those who wonder if the Burger Week stampede will threaten their ability to deliver all hand-done patties, Elephants says, 'Bring it.'
properties.name: The Pig Lebowski
